newsitem.title: UK: Sterling locked in ranges in quiet European trade.
newsitem.headline: Sterling locked in ranges in quiet European trade.

text.p: Sterling was well-supported within tight ranges in quiet European trade on Tuesday as markets lulled after the long Easter holiday.
"Sterling held up well despite the FTSE 100-point drop," BankAmerica economist Jeremy Hawkins said. "People are looking for UK interest rates to move up in line with the U.S."
Sterling was quoted at 2.7420/30 marks by 1142 GMT compared to 2.7465/75 in late Europe on Thursday, with cable trading in a range at $1.6432/42 against $1.6450/60 on Thursday.
Fears of further hikes in UK interest rates are providing sterling with underlying support, according to economists.
"The UK, which is expected to increase rates after the general election, is better placed to follow the Fed than most European countries which are looking to bring rates down," Hawkins said.
"The dislocation in economic cycles between the UK and continental Europe continues to support sterling," he added.
The pound ignored March UK Purchasing Managers Index data which showed purchasing managers reported a 10th consecutive monthly rise in output and new orders.
The overall PMI, however, edged slightly lower to a seasonally-adjusted 52.9 from 53.4 in February, largely due to a drop in manufacturing employment.
